Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Sources and ecosystem significance of dust inputs during extremely wet and dry years in the Sierra Nevada, California
Award.AbstractNarration:
Investigators have shown that, during drought, dust is important to soils in the Sierra Nevada, California (CA) and it is entering the Sierra from both the Central Valley (CA) and from the Gobi Desert, China, and that both sources bring in high-nutrient dust. These results are based on analyses of dust collected at the peak of the recent 2012-2016 drought, raising the question of whether the same trends would be observed during a wet year. Here, the team will collect new dust samples monthly to bi-monthly during the summer of 2017, following the recent wet winter of 2016-2017, from the same four elevations of the Southern Sierra Critical Zone Observatory that were used in previous research. In addition, they will collect shallow topsoil samples for comparison. They will then begin to describe the microbial community of the dust and soil from 2017, and to analyze the origin of dust entering the Sierra in the dry seasons of 2015, a dry year, and 2017, a wet year. The research will involve three graduate students and a postdoctoral scientist, as well as underserved minority undergraduates from both University of California (UC) Riverside and Merced, both Hispanic Serving Institutions. This project will be an excellent opportunity for educational and professional development. Additionally, the participating postdoctoral scientist takes part in a residential summer institute in Earth System Science for American Indian and Alaska Native high school students at UC Irvine. The research from this project will be disseminated during the summer institute in an effort to interest students in the interplay between climate and Earth surface processes.

Dust has long been recognized as a vital source of nutrients in slowly eroding tropical ecosystems where intense weathering limits nutrient inputs from underlying bedrock. Investigators' recent work along an actively eroding montane landscape in the Sierra Nevada, California (CA) revealed large contributions of dust from both regional and transoceanic sources; growth-limiting nutrients (e.g., phosphorus) were determined to be supplied at rates on par with those from underlying bedrock weathering. This work also shows that microbial communities in dust varied between elevations, and community composition contained very few overlapping sequences with co-located soil communities. Also, the contributions from the Central Valley to mid-elevation sites increased substantially over the summer dry period, suggesting that the relative importance of regional dust sources to these ecosystems increases as the time since the last significant precipitation event increases. Analyses thus far have been based on dust inputs collected (2014) at the peak of the recent 2012-2016 drought, raising the question of whether findings are sensitive to changes in dust sources and emissions. The proposed work will begin to evaluate this question by analyzing the provenance and nutrients of dust collected during another drought-year summer (2015), and collecting new samples throughout the summer of 2017, after a wet year, with the goal of analyzing them in the near future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The generation and transport of dust is related to climate – across seasonal and annual timescales – as well as land-use and landscape characteristics. The production and transport of dust can be amplified by global and regional droughts, and can deliver important nutrients to far off ecosystems. Indeed, dust serves as an external input and resource to nutrient poor ecosystems, especially in slowly-eroding ecosystems where intense weathering may limit nutrient inputs from underlying bedrock. In mountain ecosystems, where bedrock conversion to soil provides continuous nutrient supply, one important, yet often overlooked, aspect of these inputs is the functional role of dust as a vector for microbial dispersal, as dust can serve as a platform for translocating microorganisms. Thus, we examined dust to better understand how regional and climatic trends impact its biophysical composition.

As mountains are natural laboratories for climate change, often warmer and drier at lower elevations and cooler and wetter at highest elevations, we used an elevation gradient in California’s Sierra Nevada Mountains to examine the effects of temperature and moisture on dust. We collected and analyzed incoming dust samples, as well as ambient topsoil, across four elevations in this mountain range to evaluate the relative contributions of drought, distance, and spatial features on dust biophysical properties. Specifically, we sampled along this elevation gradient to quantify trace elemental and isotopic concentrations and characterize microbiomes of dust collected across two unusually dry years as compared with an unusually wet year to examine how these factors influence the amount, origin, nutrient balance, and microbiomes of incoming dust to California’s Sierra Nevada Mountains.

We compared the origin and amount of dust from the two dry (drought) years: 2014 and 2015 samples. To add to our previous findings about dust from the first drought year, we analyzed trace elements in dust from the second drought year. We acid-digested the dust and conducted mass spectrometry to compare the interannual trace metal and macronutrient concentrations across these two drought years. In combination with trace element concentrations, we used strontium (Sr) and neodymium (Nd) isotopes to quantify the role of regionally- versus globally-supplied dust in nutrient delivery to this mountain ecosystem. We isotopically fingerprinted our sampled dust, to determine the relative inputs of Central Valley-derived dust-- a notorious regional source of dust in California-- versus Asian-derived dust, a globally relevant source of transoceanic dust. Moreover, we examined spatial and intra-annual variability, by collecting samples across elevations at multiple times point each year, during California’s dry season. 

During the dry season of the second drought year, Asian sources contributed between 10 and 40% of dust to sites located along our elevational transect, and increased in relative abundance during the summer growing season as compared to regional dust sources. In contrast to our previous findings, these changes are likely related to the prolonged drought in Asia during the second drought year; this remarkable interannual pattern was a surprising discovery. These analyses highlight both the sensitivity of dust production and transport to drought and the teleconnections of dust transport in terrestrial ecosystems.

Using molecular techniques, paired with isotopic analyses, we examined spatiotemporal variation in dust-associated microbial communities as exogenous inputs along the elevation gradient. We completed sequencing dust samples from both drought years for both fungi and bacterial, and completed the bioinformatics and final statistical analyses. Both fungal and bacterial community composition and the functional capacity of these communities differed spatially and temporally, and were significantly correlated with the original location of these dust-driven inputs. Additionally, we determined that the microbiome of the dust differed temporally and spatially by site, which covaried with elevation. We detected a subset of macronutrient and trace metal concentrations that correlated with dust microbiome structure. Elevation strongly predicted microbial community composition. Our analyses revealed four main networks of co-occurring fungi, which correlated with each site sampled, at increasing elevations; low elevation fungi were functionally and phylogenetically distinct from high elevation fungi, which had traits that promoted their persistence within inhospitable environments. Interestingly, we found greater numbers of fungal pathogens at lowest elevations, with the most decomposer and mutualistic fungi found at the highest elevation site. We are currently drafting a manuscript highlighting these results 

A portion of this research was published in Aeolian Research and was presented at numerous venues including meetings of professional societies and academic departmental seminars. Furthermore, an award-winning documentary entitled: Dust Rising, featured our NSF funded research – highlighting both our field work and laboratory analyses – and underscored the associated implications of our work for both human health and conservation. This elevation gradient was a part of the Southern Sierra Critical Zone Observatory. Our research in the Sierra Nevada of California reveals both nutrient and microbial inputs from both regional and transoceanic dust sources, and that the contribution of each source changes over time.
